candidates.title: Did a KGB Agent Confirm That the Sex Pistols Were Backed by the USSR to Destabilize the West?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A KGB agent admitted that the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 9 May 2017, Facebook page "The Church of PUNK" shared an article reporting that a KGB agent admitted the band the Sex Pistols were an operation backed by the former Soviet Union to destabilize Western democracy:
The April 2015 article reported that at the time it was published, a former KGB agent had just disclosed the punk rock plot:
Alexandrei Varennikovic Voloshin, a retired KGB agent, has admitted this week on National Russian Television (NTV) that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) was behind the creation of the 1970s punk scene and financed major punk bands such as the Sex Pistols, the Clash and the Ramones.
The USSR government at the time spent hundreds of millions of rubles on this covert operation destined to create utter chaos and pervert the Western youth to nihilist, anti-establishment and anti-american ideologies he explained in an hour long interview broadcast on national television.
There is no truth to this story; World News Daily Report states on its own disclaimer page that all of the content on the site is fictional:
WNDR assumes however all responsibility for the satirical nature of its articles and for the fictional nature of their content. All characters appearing in the articles in this website  even those based on real people  are entirely fictional and any resemblance between them and any persons, living, dead, or undead is purely a miracle.
candidates.description: A Facebook page for punk fans recirculated an old (and fake) story that the Sex Pistols were a KGB plot to foment dissent in the West.

result.explanation: The claim that a KGB agent admitted the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy is FALSE.  Snopes.com debunks this claim, stating that the story originated from a satirical website, World News Daily Report, which explicitly states that all its content is fictional.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes.com fact-check explicitly states the story is false and originated from a satirical website, which admits its content is fictional.

final_result.explanation:
The original news caption claims that a KGB agent admitted the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy. This claim is completely unfounded based on both internal and external validation.

Internal validation reveals a significant mismatch between the image and the caption. The image shows a singer performing, with no visual elements related to the KGB, Sex Pistols, USSR, or Western democracy.  There's no visual evidence to support any of the entities mentioned in the caption. The internal check gives a confidence score of 0, indicating a complete lack of visual support for the caption's claim.

External validation strongly refutes the claim. A fact-check from Snopes.com confirms that the story is false and originated from a satirical website, World News Daily Report, which explicitly states that its content is fictional. This external source provides robust evidence against the caption's claim, giving a high confidence score of 10. The external evidence confirms that the connection between the Sex Pistols, the USSR, and a KGB admission of funding to destabilize Western democracy is entirely fabricated.

There is no discrepancy between the internal and external checks. Both conclusively show that the caption is out of context and completely false. The image shows a singer; the caption makes a false and unsubstantiated claim about the Sex Pistols and the USSR.  Therefore, the final verdict is that the caption is out of context and should not be associated with this image.

The high confidence score of 10 reflects the strong evidence from both internal and external checks, leaving no room for doubt regarding the falsity and out-of-context nature of the caption.  There's no uncertainty or ambiguity because both methods of validation align perfectly in their rejection of the caption's claim.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation methods strongly reject the original caption. Internal analysis finds no visual connection between the image and the entities in the caption, while external fact-checking reveals the caption's claim to be a fabricated story from a satirical website.  There is complete agreement between both validation methods resulting in a high confidence score.
